ApplyConfigToMachineGroup.document: This API is used to apply the collection configuration to the specified machine group.
ApplyConfigToMachineGroup.name: Applies collection configuration to specified machine group

CreateAlarm.document: This API is used to create an alarm policy.
CreateAlarm.name: Creates alarm policy

CreateAlarmNotice.document: This API is used to create a notification group.
CreateAlarmNotice.name: Creates a notification group

CreateConfig.document: This API is used to create a collection rule configuration.
CreateConfig.name: Creates collection rule configuration

CreateConsumer.document: This API is used to create a shipping task.

CreateExport.document: This API is used to create a download task to export raw logs.
CreateExport.name: Creates log download task

CreateIndex.document: This API is used to create an index.

CreateLogset.document: This API is used to create a logset. The ID of the created logset is returned.

CreateMachineGroup.document: This API is used to create a machine group.
CreateMachineGroup.name: Creates machine group

CreateTopic.document: This API is used to create a log topic.
CreateTopic.name: Creates log topic

DeleteAlarm.document: This API is used to delete an alarm policy.
DeleteAlarm.name: Deletes alarm policy

DeleteAlarmNotice.document: This API is used to delete a notification group.
DeleteAlarmNotice.name: Deletes a notification group

DeleteConfig.document: This API is used to delete a collection rule configuration.
DeleteConfig.name: Deletes collection rule configuration

DeleteConfigFromMachineGroup.document: This API is used to delete the collection configuration applied to a machine group.
DeleteConfigFromMachineGroup.name: Deletes collection configuration applied to machine group

DeleteConsumer.document: This API is used to delete a shipping task.
DeleteConsumer.name: Deletes a shipping task

DeleteExport.document: This API is used to delete a log download task.
DeleteExport.name: Deletes log download task

DeleteIndex.document: This API is used to delete the index configuration of a log topic. After deleting, you cannot retrieve or query the collected logs.
DeleteIndex.name: Deletes index configuration

DeleteLogset.document: This API is used to delete a logset.
DeleteLogset.name: Deletes logset

DeleteMachineGroup.document: This API is used to delete a machine group.
DeleteMachineGroup.name: Deletes machine group

DeleteShipper.document: This API is used to delete a shipping rule.
DeleteShipper.name: Deletes shipping rule

DeleteTopic.document: This API is used to delete a log topic.
DeleteTopic.name: Deletes log topic

DescribeAlarmNotices.document: This API is used to get the notification group list.
DescribeAlarmNotices.name: Gets the notification group list

DescribeAlarms.document: This API is used to get the alarm policy list.
DescribeAlarms.name: Gets the list of alarm policies

DescribeConfigMachineGroups.document: This API is used to get the machine group bound to a collection rule configuration.
DescribeConfigMachineGroups.name: Gets machine group bound to collection rule configuration

DescribeConfigs.document: This API is used to get a collection rule configuration.
DescribeConfigs.name: Gets collection rule configuration

DescribeConsumer.document: This API is used to query a shipping task.
DescribeConsumer.name: Queries a shipping task

DescribeExports.document: This API is used to get the list of log download tasks.
DescribeExports.name: Gets the list of log download tasks

DescribeIndex.document: This API is used to get the index configuration information.
DescribeIndex.name: Gets index configuration information

DescribeLogContext.document: This API is used to search for content in the log context.
DescribeLogContext.name: Searches in context

DescribeLogHistogram.document: This API is used to build a histogram.
DescribeLogHistogram.name: DescribeLogHistogram

DescribeLogsets.document: This API is used to get the list of logsets.
DescribeLogsets.name: Gets the list of logsets

DescribeMachineGroupConfigs.document: This API is used to get the collection rule configuration bound to a machine group.
DescribeMachineGroupConfigs.name: Gets collection rule configuration bound to machine group

DescribeMachineGroups.document: This API is used to get the list of machine groups.
DescribeMachineGroups.name: Gets the list of machine groups

DescribeMachines.document: This API is used to get the machine status in the specified machine group.
DescribeMachines.name: Gets machine status

DescribePartitions.document: This API is used to get the list of topic partitions.
DescribePartitions.name: Gets the list of partitions

DescribeShipperTasks.document: This API is used to get the list of shipping tasks.
DescribeShipperTasks.name: Gets the list of shipping tasks

DescribeShippers.document: This API is used to get the list of shipping rules.
DescribeShippers.name: Gets the list of shipping rules

DescribeTopics.document: This API is used to get the list of log topics and supports pagination.
DescribeTopics.name: Gets the list of log topics

GetAlarmLog.document: This API is used to get the records of alarm tasks.
GetAlarmLog.name: Gets the records of alarm tasks

MergePartition.document: This API is used to merge a topic partition in read/write state. During merge, a topic partition ID can be specified, and CLS will automatically merge the partition adjacent to the right of the range.
MergePartition.name: Merges partitions

ModifyAlarm.document: This API is used to modify an alarm policy. At least one valid configuration item needs to be modified.
ModifyAlarm.name: Modifies alarm policy

ModifyAlarmNotice.document: This API is used to modify a notification group.
ModifyAlarmNotice.name: Modifies a notification group

ModifyConfig.document: This API is used to modify a collection rule configuration.
ModifyConfig.name: Modifies collection rule configuration

ModifyConsumer.document: This API is used to modify a shipping task.
ModifyConsumer.name: Modifies a shipping task

ModifyIndex.document: This API is used to modify the index configuration.
ModifyIndex.name: Modifies index

ModifyLogset.document: This API is used to modify a logset.
ModifyLogset.name: Modifies logset

ModifyMachineGroup.document: This API is used to modify a machine group.
ModifyMachineGroup.name: Modifies machine group

ModifyShipper.document: This API is used to modify an existing shipping rule. To use this API, you need to grant CLS the write permission of the specified bucket.
ModifyShipper.name: Modifies shipping rule

RetryShipperTask.document: This API is used to retry a failed shipping task.
RetryShipperTask.name: Retries failed shipping task

SearchLog.document: This API is used to search logs. It is subject to the default API rate limit, and the number of concurrent queries to the same log topic cannot exceed 15.
SearchLog.name: SearchLog

SplitPartition.document: This API is used to split a topic partition.
SplitPartition.name: Splits topic partition

UploadLog.document:
## Note To ensure log data reliability and help you use CLS more efficiently, you are advised to use the optimized API [Uploading Structured Logs](https://intl.cloud.tencent.com/document/api/614/16873) to upload logs. For the optimized API, we have developed an SDK (available in multiple languages) that provides features including async sending, resource control, automatic retry, graceful shutdown, and detection-based reporting. For details, see [Collection via SDK](https://intl.cloud.tencent.com/document/product/614/67157?from_cn_redirect=1). `UploadLog` allows you to synchronously upload log data. If you still want to continue to use this API instead of the optimized one, read this document. ## Feature Description This API is used to write logs to a specified log topic. CLS provides the following two modes: #### Load balancing mode In this mode, logs will be automatically written to a target partition among all readable/writable partitions under the current log topic based on the load balancing principle. This mode is suitable for scenarios where sequential consumption is not needed. #### Hash routing mode In this mode, data will be written to a target partition that meets the range requirements based on the carried hash value (`X-CLS-HashKey`). For example, a log source can be bound to a topic partition through `HashKey`, strictly guaranteeing the sequence of the data written to and consumed in this partition. In addition, CLS allows you to upload logs in the following two modes: #### Input parameters (pb binary streams in `body`) | Parameter | Type | Location | Required | Description | | ------------ | ------- | ---- | ---- | ------------------------------------------------------------ | | logGroupList | message | pb | Yes | The `logGroup` list, which describes the encapsulated log groups. We recommend you enter up to 5 `logGroup` values. | `LogGroup` description: | Parameter | Required | Description | | ----------- | -------- | ------------------------------------------------------------ | | logs | Yes | Log array consisting of multiple `Log` values. The `Log` indicates a log, and a `LogGroup` can contain up to 10,000 `Log` values. | | contextFlow | No | Unique `LogGroup` ID, which should be passed in if the context feature needs to be used. Format: "{context ID}-{LogGroupID}".
Context ID: Uniquely identifies the context (a series of log files that are continuously scrolling or a series of logs that need to be sequenced), which is a 64-bit integer hex string.
LogGroupID: A 64-bit integer hex string that continuously increases, such as `102700A66102516A-59F59`. | | filename | No | Log filename | | source | No | Log source, which is generally the machine IP | | logTags | No | Tag list of logs | `Log` description: | Parameter | Required | Description | | -------- | -------- | ------------------------------------------------------------ | | time | Yes | Unix timestamp of log time in seconds or milliseconds (recommended) | | contents | No | Log content in key-value format. A log can contain multiple key-value pairs. | `Content` description: | Parameter | Required | Description | | ------ | -------- | ------------------------------------------------------------ | | key | Yes | Key of a field group in one log, which cannot start with `_`. | | value | Yes | Value of a field group. The `value` of one log cannot exceed 1 MB and the total `value` in `LogGroup` cannot exceed 5 MB. | `LogTag` description: | Parameter | Required | Description | | ------ | -------- | -------------------------------- | | key | Yes | Key of a custom tag | | value | Yes | Value corresponding to the custom tag key | ## pb Compilation Sample This sample describes how to use the protoc compiler to compile the pb description file into a log upload API in C++. > ?Currently, protoc supports compilation in multiple programming languages such as Java, C++, and Python. For more information, see [protoc](https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf). #### 1. Install Protocol Buffers Download [Protocol Buffers](https://main.qcloudimg.com/raw/d7810aaf8b3073fbbc9d4049c21532aa/protobuf-2.6.1.tar.gz), decompress the package, and install the tool. The version used in the sample is protobuf 2.6.1 running on CentOS 7.3. Run the following command to decompress the `protobuf-2.6.1.tar.gz` package to the `/usr/local` directory and go to the directory: ``` tar -zxvf protobuf-2.6.1.tar.gz -C /usr/local/ && cd /usr/local/protobuf-2.6.1 ``` Run the following commands to start compilation and installation, and configure the environment variables: ``` [root@VM_0_8_centos protobuf-2.6.1]# ./configure [root@VM_0_8_centos protobuf-2.6.1]# make && make install [root@VM_0_8_centos protobuf-2.6.1]# export PATH=$PATH:/usr/local/protobuf-2.6.1/bin ``` After the compilation succeeds, run the following command to check the version: ``` [root@VM_0_8_centos protobuf-2.6.1]# protoc --version liprotoc 2.6.1 ``` #### 2. Create a pb description file A pb description file is an agreed-on data interchange format for communication. To upload logs, compile the specified protocol format to an API in the target programming language and add the API to the project code. For more information, see [protoc](https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf). Create a pb message description file `cls.proto` based on the pb data format content specified by CLS. > !The pb description file content cannot be modified, and the filename must end with `.proto`. The content of `cls.proto` (pb description file) is as follows: ``` package cls; message Log { message Content { required string key = 1; // Key of each field group required string value = 2; // Value of each field group } required int64 time = 1; // Unix timestamp repeated Content contents = 2; // Multiple key-value pairs in one log } message LogTag { required string key = 1; required string value = 2; } message LogGroup { repeated Log logs = 1; // Log array consisting of multiple logs optional string contextFlow = 2; // This parameter does not take effect currently optional string filename = 3; // Log filename optional string source = 4; // Log source, which is generally the machine IP repeated LogTag logTags = 5; } message LogGroupList { repeated LogGroup logGroupList = 1; // Log group list } ``` #### 3. Compile and generate the API This sample uses the proto compiler to generate a C++ file in the same directory as the `cls.proto` file. Run the following compilation command: ``` protoc --cpp_out=./ ./cls.proto ``` > ?`--cpp_out=./ ` indicates that the file will be compiled in cpp format and output to the current directory. `./cls.proto` indicates the `cls.proto` description file in the current directory. After the compilation succeeds, the code file in the corresponding programming language will be generated. This sample generates the `cls.pb.h` header file and [cls.pb.cc](http://cls.pb.cc) code implementation file as shown below: ``` [root@VM_0_8_centos protobuf-2.6.1]# protoc --cpp_out=./ ./cls.proto [root@VM_0_8_centos protobuf-2.6.1]# ls cls.pb.cc cls.pb.h cls.proto ``` #### 4. Call the API Import the generated `cls.pb.h` header file into the code and call the API for data encapsulation.
UploadLog.name: Uploads log

members.document:
• `topicName` filters by **log topic name**. Type: String. Required: No
  • `logsetName` filters by **logset name**. Type: String. Required: No
  • `topicId` filters by **log topic ID**. Type: String. Required: No
  • `logsetId` filters by **logset ID**. You can call DescribeLogsets to query the list of created logsets or log in to the console to view them. You can also call CreateLogset to create a logset. Type: String. Required: No
  • `tagKey` filters by **tag key**. Type: String. Required: No
  • `tag:tagKey` filters by **tag key-value pair**. The tagKey should be replaced with a specified tag key, such as tag:exampleKey. Type: String. Required: No
  • `storageType` filters by **log topic storage type**. Valid values: `hot` (real-time storage); `cold`: (IA storage). Type: String. Required: No. Each request can contain up to 10 `Filters` and 100 `Filter.Values`.

Key name of each extracted field. An empty key indicates to discard the field. This parameter is valid only if `log_type` is `delimiter_log`. `json_log` logs use the key of JSON itself

members.document: If the value is `true`, the new search method will be used, and the response parameters `AnalysisRecords` and `Columns` will be valid. If the value is `false`, the old search method will be used, and `AnalysisResults` and `ColNames` will be valid.

members.name: Tags

members.document: Whether to enable automatic update for the machine group
members.name: AutoUpdate

members.document: Update start time. We recommend you update LogListener during off-peak hours.
members.name: UpdateStartTime

members.document: Update end time. We recommend you update LogListener during off-peak hours.
members.name: UpdateEndTime

members.document: Whether to enable the service log to record the logs generated by the LogListener service itself. After it is enabled, the internal logset `cls_service_logging` and the `loglistener_status`, `loglistener_alarm`, and `loglistener_business` log topics will be created, which will not incur fees.
members.name: ServiceLogging

members.document: Shipping time interval in seconds. Default value: 300. Value range: 300–900
members.name: Interval

members.document: Maximum size of a file to be shipped, in MB. Default value: 256. Value range: 100–256
members.name: MaxSize

members.document: Filter rules for shipped logs. Only logs matching the rules can be shipped. All rules are in the AND relationship, and up to five rules can be added. If the array is empty, no filtering will be performed, and all logs will be shipped.
members.name: FilterRules

members.document: Partition rule of shipped log, which can be represented in `strftime` time format

MonitorTime.document: Monitoring task execution time point in alarm policy

members.document:
Valid values:
  • `Period`: periodic execution
  • `Fixed`: scheduled execution
members.name: Type

members.document: Execution interval or scheduled time point in minutes. Value range: 1–1440.
members.name: Time

members.document:
Recipient type. Valid values:
  • `Uin`: user ID
  • `Group`: user group ID Currently, other recipient types are not supported.
members.name: ReceiverType

members.document:
Notification method
  • `Email`: email
  • `Sms`: SMS
  • `WeChat`: WeChat
  • `Phone`: phone

Full-Text index configuration

Key-Value index configuration

Metafield index configuration

members.document: Case sensitivity
members.name: CaseSensitive

members.document: Key-Value pair information of the index to be created. Up to 100 key-value pairs can be configured.
members.name: KeyValues

members.document: Case sensitivity
members.name: CaseSensitive

members.document: Field information in the metafield index configuration
members.name: KeyValues

members.document: ID of the log topic to be searched
members.name: TopicId

members.document: Start time of the log to be searched, which is a Unix timestamp in milliseconds
members.name: From

members.document: End time of the log to be searched, which is a Unix timestamp in milliseconds
members.name: To

members.document: Statement for search and analysis. Maximum length: 12 KB A statement is in the format of [search rule] | [SQL statement]. You can omit the pipe symbol | and SQL statement when log analysis is not required.
members.name: Query

members.document: The number of raw logs returned by a single query. Maximum value: 1000. You need to use `Context` to continue to get logs. Notes: * This parameter is valid only when the query statement (`Query`) does not contain an SQL statement. * To limit the number of analysis results, see SQL LIMIT Syntax.
members.name: Limit

members.document: You can pass through the `Context` value (validity: 1 hour) returned by the last API to continue to get logs, which can get up to 10,000 raw logs. Notes: * This parameter is valid only when the query statement (`Query`) does not contain an SQL statement. * To continue to get analysis results, see SQL LIMIT Syntax.
members.name: Context

members.document: Time order of the logs returned. Valid values: `asc` (ascending); `desc`: (descending). Default value: `desc` Notes: * This parameter is valid only when the query statement (`Query`) does not contain an SQL statement. * To sort the analysis results, see SQL ORDER BY Syntax.
members.name: Sort

members.document:
If the value is `true`, the new response method will be used, and the output parameters `AnalysisRecords` and `Columns` will be valid.
If the value is `false`, the old response method will be used, and the output parameters `AnalysisResults` and `ColNames` will be valid.
The two response methods differ slightly in terms of encoding format. You are advised to use the new method (`true`).
members.name: UseNewAnalysis

members.document: You can pass through the `Context` value (validity: 1 hour) returned by this API to continue to get more logs.
members.name: Context

members.document:
Whether to return all raw log query results. If not, you can use `Context` to continue to get logs.
Note: This parameter is valid only when the query statement (`Query`) does not contain an SQL statement.
members.name: ListOver

members.document: Whether the returned data is the analysis (SQL) result
members.name: Analysis

members.document:
Raw logs that meet the search conditions
Note: This field may return `null`, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: Results

members.document:
Column names of log analysis
This parameter is valid only when `UseNewAnalysis` is `false`.
Note: This field may return `null`, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: ColNames

members.document:
Log analysis result
This parameter is valid only when `UseNewAnalysis` is `false`.
Note: This field may return `null`, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: AnalysisResults

members.document:
Log analysis result
This parameter is valid only when `UseNewAnalysis` is `true`.
Note: This field may return `null`, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: AnalysisRecords

members.document:
Column attributes of log analysis
This parameter is valid only when `UseNewAnalysis` is `true`.
Note: This field may return `null`, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: Columns
